comment.author: 35672655@N00
comment._content:
This building stood corner of george and Wynyard streets.
Designed by Sulman & Power architects, this project gave Sulman the opportunity to demonstrate fire-retarding construction, using porous terra cotta casing elements. Built by McLeod Bros, It was the Head quarters of the Mutual Life Association of Australia & later the French Bank. The building consisted of basement & 6 upper levels.It was one of the earliest examples of a fire-resisting structure. The structure was of wrought iron beams & floor beams encased in terra cotta blocks. The staircase was also fireproof. The façade was clad in Pyrmont stone & the granite columns from Scotland.It had a 28m frontage to Wynyard St & 14m frontage to George Street .Topping out in June 22,1889, it was the citys tallest building for a few short months Although buildings such as Chief Sec Bldg & Mort & Co woolstore were approx same height of 102ft/31m, this building was built using the “skyscraper “ method. Iron frame with fast passenger lifts..The historic structure was demolished in 1969 to make way for the Bank of NZ.

cheers

comment._content: superb architecture.... it survived all the way to 1969--- a real loss

comment._content: It's disappointing to know that most of these buildings have been demolished in our city....

comment.author: 38823497@N07
comment._content:
How greed ruins the aesthetics of a city.
Sydney was once the biggest Victorian city in the world.
And still, more old buildings with character go under the hammer to be replaced by ugly flats. And now a large area of Dulwich Hill old shops look likely to go for 44 appartments, ruining the character of the place.
Its a shame!

comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Sydney's older buildings and structures. , and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: An absolutely enchanting building! The motto on the statue is: 'Praevisa mala pereunt', which I gather means 'Evils foreseen are destroyed' (or something similar). This pic appears to show the work of chalk graffitists. There are what appear to be numbers scrawled on some of the ground level blocks, and on one there's a continuous white line, possibly made whilst the graffitist was walking along with chalk in hand...all possibly the work of children playing Here's the Sydney Morning Herald report of the opening in September 1890 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28273126 The SMH's stablemate the Sydney Mail included an illustration - news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1302&dat=18900913&... The Australian Town & Country Journal also had a pictorial article - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71181810

comment.author: 35672655@N00
comment._content: ^interesting.walk graffiti? thats great. it washes off when it rains.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: When you zoom in, the Mutual Life Assurance building looks as if it's just come out of the mint! There's a little bit of debris on the mezzanine level parapet (looks a bit like cigarette buts!), and some of the pillars appear to be marked by something like bird droppings, but there's no great accumulation of the stuff, there's no accumulation of soot or grime, no water marks and rust stains, etc. So my hunch is that this pic was taken not long after the opening, ie. in late 1890 or early 1891. I gather that Troedel Cooper & Co were a Sydney branch of the Melbourne printing and lithography firm Troedel & Co. TC&Co appear to have operated in Sydney from ca. early 1890 thru to early May 1894, when Troedel & Co (the Melbourne firm) went into liquidation. They appear to have been at 41 York St (cnr York and Erskine Sts) until mid-late 1892, after which they moved to 81 Clarence St. In January 1891 there was a sizeable fire at 41 York St but TC&Co appear to have remained there afterwards...until mid/late 1892. I'm not convinced that their sign which we see in this pic is attached to 41 York St. I might be wrong, but it looks to be attached to a building in Carrington St. Maybe they rented a space on a nearby building for their sign, which might have remained there regardless of where they moved...so the sign mightn't be much help in dating this pic...beyond giving us a range ca. 1890-1894. Per the digitised newspapers, the Colonial Deposit and Discount Bank was a shonky money lending operation run by a swindler named Hastings Likely. The 'Bank' appears to have had an office at Otis Chambers, 82 King St from 1889 thru to ca. 1892, after which it appears to have ceased trading. During 1893-1894 Hastings Likely featured in a number of civil cases brought against him by people who he'd duped (a widow, a miner from the bush, etc). He was bankrupt by 1894. Of course the sign might have stayed up for some time after the 'Bank' had become past tense, but given it was occupying valuable advertising space, there's also a good chance that it might have been removed soon after the 'Bank' folded in 1892. C.A. Sherwin evidently leased a turkish bath in Bligh St during the 1880s. From the bit we can see here it's impossible to tell whether the sign was an advert for the Bligh St turkish bath, or for another turkish bath. But per this notice Sherwin's lease at the Bligh St bath ended on 30 April 1890 (column 3, 10th from bottom) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13768977 Wallach Bros flash new furniture warehouse at the corner of York and Clarence Sts opened in the later 1880s - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71098642 ; Wallach Bros appear to have gone into receivership in about 1893-1894 (maybe another casualty of the severe 1890s economic depression). R.W. Harvey, share broker, etc had an office at 335 George St in the later 1880s...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Per this brief item the statue represents Forethought protecting her family from a wolf (!)...the statue was evidently ordered up from Italy (column 4, 2nd notice) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-page1380890
